JohanMabille commented on issue #5621: ARROW-6847: [C++] Add range_expression adapter to Iterator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5621#issuecomment-542549185
 
 
   > Getting the Status on the side is a bit weird. Should we return a Result<> when iterating from the range instead?
   @JohanMabille @wolfv What would be your thoughts on this?
   
   Not sure to get why you need the iterator to fill a Status object. Anyway, the second loop written by @bkietz is indeed more natural in C++ than having to check anything in the loop body.

JohanMabille commented on issue #5621: ARROW-6847: [C++] Add range_expression adapter to Iterator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5621#issuecomment-542549185
 
 
   > Getting the Status on the side is a bit weird. Should we return a Result<> when iterating from the range instead?
   @JohanMabille @wolfv What would be your thoughts on this?
   
   Not sure to get why you need the iterator to fill a Status object. Anyway, the second loop written by @bkietz 
   
   ```cpp
   for (int i : ints.AsRange(&status)) {
     // loop body
   }
   ```
   
   is indeed more natural in C++ than having to check anything in the loop body.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

users@infra.apache.org

bkietz commented on issue #5621: ARROW-6847: [C++] Add range_expression adapter to Iterator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5621#issuecomment-542657794
 
 
   @JohanMabille the Iterator may return an error status when attempting to retrieve the next sequence element. That error needs to be accessible by the consumer of the Iterator, hence the result/side status loops.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: Iterator provides the Visit() method for visiting each element, but idiomatic C++ uses a range for loop
fields.summary: [C++] Add a range_expression interface to Iterator<>
